Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates by stating that Merrick Garland "authored an opinion that resulted in the release of 17 Guantanamo Bay prisoners," when in fact he authored an opinion that led to the release of only one detainee.
Understate: The claim understates the number of prisoners released by stating that only 17 were released, when in fact only one detainee was released.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support as it does not provide sufficient evidence or sources to verify the statement.
Problematic assumption: The claim makes a problematic assumption by implying that the released prisoners were all part of a group of violent Islamist extremists, without providing evidence to support this assumption.
Exist alternative explanation: The claim does not consider alternative explanations for the release of the prisoners, such as the possibility that they were wrongly detained or did not pose a significant threat.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that only one detainee was released, not 17 as stated.
Falters at times: The claim falters at times by conflating two court rulings and not providing accurate information about the case of the Uighur detainees.
